title: 114_hr2920
content: The "Captive Primate Safety Act" adds nonhuman primates to the list of prohibited wildlife species under the Lacey Act Amendments of 1981. The Lacey Act Amendments of 1981 are updated to include a new section (e) that prohibits various actions related to captive wildlife. The Lacey Act Amendments of 1981 now prohibit the export, transport, sale, receipt, acquisition, or purchase of live animals of certain prohibited wildlife species in interstate or foreign commerce. This prohibition does not apply to individuals who do not allow direct contact between certain animals and the public. The Lacey Act Amendments of 1981 prohibit the export, transport, sale, receipt, acquisition, or purchase of certain prohibited wildlife species. This includes apes, gibbons, siamangs, monkeys, and lorises, regardless of the animal's age. The amendments also specify changes in the requirements for accredited wildlife rehabilitators and the handling of prohibited wildlife species. The Lacey Act Amendments of 1981 update civil and criminal penalties related to prohibited wildlife species. The changes include inserting references to subsection (e) in various sections of the Act. The Lacey Act Amendments of 1981 update penalties for prohibited wildlife species by adding subsection (e) in paragraph (3) and specifying the effective date for regulations to be within 180 days of enactment. The Captive Wildlife Safety Act is amended to remove subsection (b) and clarify regulations for implementing section 3(e) of the Lacey Act Amendments of 1981.
